image.altText: A tree fern pictured in a national park.

props.synopsis: Investors could fund the creation of Victorian forests under a radical plan hatched by conservationists.

title.children: Advocates for creation of Great Forest National Park call for green bonds to help fund dream

image.altText: A security officer in a white shirt, black vest and pants looks at police officers standing near a sectioned off area.

props.synopsis: Six teenagers have been arrested after three youths were allegedly stabbed during a fight at a major shopping centre in Doncaster.

title.children: Teenagers allegedly stabbed in shopping centre food court fight

image.altText: Against a white background a hand holds a smartphone by thumb and index finger, hanging from up high.

props.synopsis: More Aussies are falling victim to an organised criminal underground selling counterfeit smartphones, designed to look and feel like the real deal.

title.children: 'Completely gutted': Aussies getting hit by criminal networks' fake phone scams

image.altText: Four people and a police officer stand near a grey car in the driveway of a brick home with a car and couch on the frontpath.

props.synopsis: A woman remains in a critical condition in hospital after being mauled by three dogs at a home in Dandenong, in Melbourne's south-east, on Thursday.

title.children: Woman attacked by dogs in Melbourne backyard remains in critical condition

image.altText: A dairy cow with a collar on

props.synopsis: Farmers around Australia are jumping on the AI bandwagon to boost production outputs and become more efficient. Experts say the technology has the potential to transform how we produce food and fibres.

title.children: How AI is allowing cows to send messages to farmers when they're giving birth

image.altText: A police sign on a Victoria Police car.

props.synopsis: It's alleged a sergeant twice performed the banned Nazi salute at the Victoria Police Academy this week.

title.children: Police sergeant suspended over Nazi salute allegations

image.altText: A middle-aged woman looks defiantly at the camera, while holding the handle of a shovel.

props.synopsis: Fed up with the threat of floods, Victorian resident Tuesday Browell is thought to be the first private Australian resident to import war-zone technology to protect her home.

title.children: Why this woman has fortified her bush home with a bulletproof, blast-proof military barrier

image.altText: Postal vote 600x600

props.synopsis: Gender parity in Victorian councils is hoped for next year, but only 40 per cent of candidates are women. So, why aren't people — including men — interested in running?

title.children: 'Makes no sense': Lack of power, wards, time burden blamed for almost 50 uncontested council elections

image.altText: Beerburrum storm

props.synopsis: Australia is facing one of the hottest summers on record according to the Bureau of Meteorology's weather modelling which tips well above average temperatures across the country.

title.children: BOM predicts one of the hottest summers on record with thunderstorms, heatwaves and severe cyclones

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Sonexay Siphandone shake hands next to a lectern, in front of a row of flags.

props.synopsis: The good news regarding Australian lobster exports wasn't the only headline out of the gathering in Laos this week, with plenty of simmering tensions in the region regarding thorny security issues.

title.children: Lobsters, tense words and a big idea dead on arrival at this week's ASEAN summit

image.altText: Five people in military gear around a white-painted armoured vehicle.

props.synopsis: The United Nations' peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon says two of its troops have been injured in explosions near an observation tower, the result of continued Israeli fire at their position.

title.children: Drones enter Israel from Lebanon amid outcry over UN peacekeepers injured in Israel fire on Lebanese UNIFIL base

image.altText: A middle-aged white man and woman in orange shirts and black masks are walked by Indonesian police down a roadway.

props.synopsis: An Australian couple, including a woman who survived the Bali terrorist bombings in 2002, have been arrested on the tourist island after police conducted raids targeting illegal prostitution.

title.children: Australian couple facing up to 12 years' prison after police raid their Bali spa business

image.altText: Anthony Albanese behind a podium.

props.synopsis: For Anthony Albanese and Labor, there hasn't been much to laugh about this week as war in the Middle East impacts politics at home, parliamentary gaffs and toxic staffer culture overshadow a worsening economic outlook.

title.children: When things are going badly in politics, even the wins end up feeling like losses

image.altText: Two women signing Uluru Statement from the Heart

props.synopsis: Speaking to the ABC's Insiders: On Background podcast, constitutional law expert Megan Davis also ruled out supporting any purely symbolic constitutional recognition for Indigenous people, and said it would be a broken promise if the Albanese government were to not proceed with establishing a Makarrata Commission.

title.children: Uluru Statement architect says she was open to calling off Voice referendum after polls showed it would fail

image.altText: Toshiyuki Mimaki at a table with three young people, holding a device in his hand and speaking into microphones.

props.synopsis: The 2024 Nobel Peace Prize has been awarded to Japanese Hibakusha organisation Nihon Hidankyo. Hibakusha is the grassroots movement for survivors of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic bombings in 1945.

title.children: Grassroots anti-nuclear movement made up of atomic bomb survivors awarded 2024 Nobel Peace Prize

image.altText: Two white wine glasses clinking

props.synopsis: When China lifted tariffs on Australia's bottled wine exports, winemakers, connoisseurs and importers were excited, but now they face new challenges and changing consumer behaviour.

title.children: Before China promised to end bans on lobster, it allowed Australian wine back in. But barely anyone is drinking

image.altText: Shoppers walk under a Catier watch advertisement.

props.synopsis: While Australian households are amongst the world's most indebted — courtesy of hefty mortgages — Chinese households are stacked to the rafters with savings. That sounds great, but it's causing real problems for the country's economy.

title.children: Beijing has finally opened the chequebook to save China's flagging economy. It may be too late

image.altText: Dozens of Indonesian soldiers in fatigues line up with rifles in hand

props.synopsis: The ABC gains rare access to Indonesia's West Papua province, speaking with Papuans ahead of the inauguration of Indonesia's new president — a former military general accused of historic human rights abuses.

title.children: A rare glimpse into West Papua and the war Indonesia does not want the world to see

image.altText: Two women wearing red aprons stand near shelves of corn and red tomatoes.

props.synopsis: Business owners say changing consumer habits, rising costs, and an increase in theft are driving many family-run stalls to the brink.

title.children: 'People shop differently now': Stall operators fear the future of markets

image.altText: Two players embrace each other after a game

props.synopsis: It's been a record-breaking year for Super Netball, but the competition has been plagued by accusations of a toxic culture at the Firebirds and ongoing racism faced by Donnell Wallam. Now a new administration, and one former Diamond, are looking to change the game.

title.children: Efforts underway to turn tide of Indigenous representation and 'toxic' culture in Australian netball

image.altText: A moving satellite image of hurricane Milton

props.synopsis: When Hurricane Milton formed, it met with waters "as warm as a hot tub". As the world continues to burn fossil fuels and ocean temperatures climb, cyclonic storms feed off the heat and become bigger, faster and nastier.

title.children: Wetter, faster, stronger: What’s fuelling the mega-hurricanes hitting the US

image.altText: A photo of a man standing outside with glasses.

props.synopsis: There's no silver bullet to suddenly ending the housing crisis, but filling some of the spare bedrooms across the country could be part of a larger housing solution.

title.children: This older Australian has been renting out his spare rooms to ease the housing crisis

image.altText: Renee is inside the cockpit flying a yet above the earth

props.synopsis: Going to Space Camp is something many kids can only dream about, but for these First Nations high-schoolers it’s become a reality. They’ll jet off to the States later this month to participate in science and technology workshops at the US Space and Rocket Centre.

title.children: It is rocket science: Space Camp for Indigenous teens building 'the next generation of leaders the world needs'

image.altText: A person seen from waist down wearing casual pants and holding a water bottle, walking on cement path in sunlight.

props.synopsis: Jury duty is an important civic duty that most people take seriously. Yet some rules keep being broken, at a significant cost to everyone involved in a trial. What can courts do?

title.children: A juror's job is to apply the law. But what happens when they're the one breaking it?

image.altText: A close up portrait of Miranda July who has curled auburn hair and blue eyes and is standing against a tiled wall

props.synopsis: All Fours threatens to shake up and change not only because of the quality of the writing but because July reaches deep and finds the small grain of universal truth at the heart of her fantastical story, so much that even its most unhinged parts start to seem possible.

title.children: Miranda July's All Fours is threatening to shake up and change — no wonder a multi-generational movement is swirling around it

image.altText: A close-up of a young Christopher Reeve smiling.

props.synopsis: Super/Man offers an intimate glimpse behind the actor's journey, from the dizzy heights of stardom to the struggle that would eventually lead to his death, at age 52.

title.children: From invincible to vulnerable: Christopher Reeve's story is one of resilience and determination

image.altText: A bee with blue stripes on a flower stem.

props.synopsis: The ABC has begun its quest to find out which native six-legged marvel is Australia's most popular insect for 2024. Six experts have selected their finalists for an online poll.

title.children: Insects are 'the little things that run the world'. Now you can help choose Australia's favourite

image.altText: A man is smiling holding a tennis racket.

props.synopsis: Comedian Adam Hills jokes his new obsession is straining his marriage, but as a leading advocate for para-standing tennis, he wants to see the sport included in the Brisbane Paralympics.

title.children: Comedian Adam Hills has a new obsession in para-standing tennis

image.altText: A grey and white seabird soaring over a grey ocean.

props.synopsis: As millions of migratory birds wing their way to our shores, avian influenza surveillance is ramping up. Here's how teams of scientists and volunteers keep tabs on wild bird health.

title.children: Big nets and blood tests: How scientists check wild birds for avian flu

image.altText: Australia's Alyssa Healy leaves the field in pain while holding her bat above head during a T20 World Cup match.

props.synopsis: Australia wicketkeeper and captain Alyssa Healy is forced to retire hurt with an "acute foot injury", while seamer Tayla Vlaeminck is cut down by yet another injury, dislocating her shoulder as Australia beats Pakistan by nine wickets.

title.children: Alyssa Healy and luckless star seamer suffer nasty injuries in Australia's T20 World Cup win over Pakistan

image.altText: A woman's hands hold a human skull.

props.synopsis: Laws banning the sale of human bones need to be reviewed to close "loopholes", legal experts say, amid a police probe into an auction house accused of selling skeletal remains.

title.children: Calls for crackdown on 'commodification of the dead'

image.altText: Middle-aged man and woman standing in front of two-storey timber beach style home with pool in front, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Prices in the small Queensland town of Keppel Sands have increased by 40 per cent in the past year, but this Victorian couple still think they got a great deal on a waterfront home.

title.children: Sleepy coastal town records first million-dollar property sale as buyers move interstate for bargains

image.altText: A woman in orange hi-vis workwear and hardhat aggressively points her finger at a middle-aged woman in a black t-shirt.

props.synopsis: A complaint made by two supporters of native forest logging who alleged they were discriminated against based on their political beliefs after being denied entry to a Bob Brown documentary sixteen months ago have had their case dismissed.

title.children: Pro-logging protesters tried to disrupt two film screenings in Tasmania. It ended in confrontation

image.altText: A pink and yellow hue aurora in the night sky by the beach

props.synopsis: The aurora australis has returned, lighting up the skies in intense colours over southern states. If you missed out on seeing it last night you may get another chance.

title.children: 'Enchanting' aurora display wows photographers and stargazers
